%text \textbf{\small{Proper \& improper rational functions}} $f(x) = \dfrac{p(x)}{q(x)}$, is a \underline\text{proper rational function} if the degree of $p(x) <$ degree of $q(x)$. Otherwise, it is \underline\text{improper} For example, $f(x) = \frac{x}{x^2 +1}$ is proper but $g(x) = \frac{x^2}{x^2 + 1 }$ is not A rational function will take one of the following forms when expressed as the sum of partial fractions % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NN}
\hline \text{Form} & \text{Partial fractions} \\ \hline \text{(Improper)} & A(x) + \frac{B(x)}{C(x)} \\ \hline \frac{px + q}{(x-a)\cdot (x-b)} & \frac{A}{x-a} + \frac{B}{x-b} \\ \hline \frac{px + q}{(x-a)^2} & \frac{A}{x-a} + \frac{B}{(x-a)^2} \\ \hline \frac{px^2 + qx + r}{(x-a)\cdot (x-b)\cdot (x-c)} & \frac{A}{x-a} + \frac{B}{x-b} + \frac{C}{x-c} \\ \hline \frac{px^2 + qx + r}{(x-a)^2\cdot (x-b)} & \frac{A}{x-a} + \frac{B}{(x-a)^2} + \frac{C}{x-b} \\ \hline \frac{px^2 + qx + r}{(x-a)\cdot (x^2+bx+c)} & \frac{A}{x-a} + \frac{Bx+C}{(x^2+bx+c)} \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text %
